poem:
"An Echo of Voices Past"

In the austere halls of rulers,
A whisper creeps, ancestral, reverent.
Anishininiimowin woven into tapestry of time,
Striking chords once thought extinct,
Pulled from the throat of a First Nation.
Language, blood-borne, echoes past wrongs,
Ontario listens with all its vast expanse,
Compelled to honour.
Sol Mamakwa speaks, the North stirs,
His people's voice, echoed in his heart,
Breathes warmth into the cold present.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "In historic first, Canada lawmaker addresses legislature in Indigenous language A First Nations lawmaker in Ontario has addressed the province’s legislature in Anishininiimowin, in a “historic” milestone that repudiates a centuries-long colonial “war” on Indigenous languages. Sol Mamakwa, a New Democratic party member from the community of Kingfisher Lake First Nation, rose on Tuesday to give the province’s first-ever Indigenous language speech in Queen’s Park, telling colleagues the moment left him feeling “thankful and proud”.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
